Christian Kohlschuetter wrote:

> On Monday 14 February 2005 22:28, stack wrote:
> > Christian Kohlschuetter wrote:
> > > One big disadvantage of my current BdbFrontier-approach is of 
> course the
> > > slow-down which occurs after about 500.000 pages (goes down from 
> about 80
> > > pages/sec. to 20). As far as I can tell, it's caused by continous
> > > page-seen
> > > lookups, which is log(n), but I might be wrong. Any ideas?
> >
> > Check out the frontier/thread reports for what it says its doing when
> > crawl is running slow.  Are all threads occupied?  Are they all stuck
> > waiting at a particular step processing?  Perhaps you need to up your #
> > of queues?
> >
> > The already-seen lookup shouldn't be noticeable for numbers as small as
> > 500k: ~3ms an insert when the db is that small (See the bdb section on
> > this page -- 
> http://crawler.archive.org/cgi-bin/wiki.pl?AlreadySeen). 
> <http://crawler.archive.org/cgi-bin/wiki.pl?AlreadySeen%29.>
> > It uses bdb -- a b-tree -- so, yeah, log n.
> >
> > St.Ack
>
> I managed to solve the speed decrease, but I am not sure if it's much 
> slower
> than you would expect. What would be the expected processing speed of 
> a broad
> crawl on a decent machine? Do you have benchmarks?

What did you change Christian?

We don't have any broad crawl benchmarks.  Benchmarking is a little 
awkward considering numbers can vary wildly if any one of myriad factors 
differs between crawls (Would probably pay us to set up crawling in a 
controlled environment to contrast crawl performance between versions or 
across major feature additions/changes).

St.Ack
